title: How to stop setting unrealistic goals and making life hard for myself - Quora

response.answer_text: Do we really need to have specific goals at all times? I want to lose 15 pounds in a month. I want to crack the toughest exam in my country this year. I want to have a million dollars before I turn 30. I want to score 90% is my upcoming exam. Can you spot any pattern between the statements? Let me help you. They are all goals. Whatever criteria you use from simple SMART technique to more sophisticated forms, they’re goals and you could easily tell at any point in time whether you succeeded or failed. It’s largely binary. Now let’s look it the other way. Losing 15 pounds in 30 days is a goal. But would anyone be able to sustain it once they reach their goal if they revert to their old patterns? They probably won’t until and unless they keep on setting newer and newer goals. Likewise, it initially amazed me when people had single academic goals. They would set a target entrance examination and revolve their entire life around it. Rather than just setting goals and then feeling the thrill for a time, why not resort to a long-lasting method of studying regularly and setting up a real insane work ethic that would aid you more than thousands of temporary goals you set. I was short for words to describe the technique though that was exactly what I was drawn into for the most part of my adult life. A part of the contribution was from most self-help gurus who argue that without specific goals your life is utterly worthless. Then things changed when I read “How to Fail at Almost Everything and Still Win Big” by Scott Adams which dedicated an entire chapter explaining goals vs systems. I would highly recommend the book for anyone wanting practical wisdom in their lives. In the author’s own words: “A goal is a specific objective that you either achieve or don’t sometime in the future. A system is something you do on a regular basis that increases your odds of success in the long run. If you do something regularly, it’s a system. If you’re waiting to achieve it someday in the future, it’s a goal. Goals are a reach-it-and-be-done situation, whereas a system is something you do on a regular basis with a reasonable expectation that doing so will get you to a better place in your life. Systems have no deadlines, and on any given day you probably can’t tell if they’re moving you in the right direction.” There is definitely a significant degree of overlap between the two terms. Every system has a goal however vague and every goal need a system for a time being. And I am not at all against goal setting. They are incredible at many times but for a more lasting change, you must follow a system. Scott explained it splendidly. For example, if your goal is to lose ten pounds, you will spend every moment until you reach the goal—if you reach it at all—feeling as if you were short of your goal. In other words, hardcore goal-oriented people exist in a state of nearly continuous failure that they hope will be temporary. That feeling wears on you. In time, it becomes heavy and uncomfortable. It might even drive you out of the game. If you achieve your goal, you celebrate and feel terrific, but only until you realize you just lost the thing that gave you purpose and direction. Your options are to feel empty and useless, perhaps enjoying the spoils of your success until they bore you, or set new goals and reenter the cycle of permanent pre-success failure. Eating healthy is a system. You can expect to have a positive impact on the system in your life. Losing 15 pounds in 30 days is a goal. Once you get there the goal doesn’t exist. After that you have two choices: 1. Revert to the system of eating healthy 2. Set a new weight loss goal and repeat the cycle Systems are liberating. If you have to do it every single day of your life, you would adapt to it much faster than when you convince yourself to do it for the next thirty days. If your only aim is to work insanely hard till you get into the top university, you would start having issues with your work ethic once you get into college if the external pressures are not sufficient to make you work hard. Bottom line: Goals are very important but having an important system is priceless.

When you set an “unrealistic” goal for yourself most often than not your goal setting is being influenced by certain personalities who have attained immense success, name & fame, which you wanted to emulate/ replicate in your life. Though on face of it, it looks ‘good’ for you to set high goals and work towards them, however “purely on a pragmatic level” many of us at the end of the day, find ourselves getting disappointed of not being able to achieve those goals which are not “realistic” considering our life situation. Why it is so? It is so because, as each success story is unique to each of the individuals involved and particular to the circumstances that he/she had faced which may not be feasible to our life situation. Thus have a broader goal which you aim to achieve and be flexible enough to make necessary course corrections to modify your goal based on the lessons you are learning in the process of pursuing your long term goal. The beauty of our life journey is such that you cannot predict how your life trajectory pans out, that being so it is always prudent to adopt flexible approach then maintaining rigidity by harping on some unrealistic yardstick which if not achieved would tend to demoralize you, by making you to think that you have failed to achieve aim/ goal set as bench-mark.

upvoters.user_id: Sourabh Kumar Mishra ( सौरभ कुमार मिश्रा)

response.answer_text: There were 200 warriors guarding a fort. All their army was killed by the 20,000 fighters of enemy. Surrendering was the only practical option. The goal to protect their fort, their pride and self esteem was quite unrealistic. Death was almost certain unless they picked up the white flag and bowed down to enemy. But none of them thought about loss, death or martyrdom. They set a goal to fight till their last breathe. Finally, the enemy broke the main gate of the fort early morning next day. They jumped in the war of death with excitement and pride. Enemy was surprised to see the magnificient skills and determination of the handful of soldiers. Finally all of them were martyred. They died like winners because they achieved their goal. None of them took their last breath with regret.  Nothing unique about this story. We must have heard such stories before and watched them in movies as well. But the important point to be noted is that the brave soldiers didn't set a target to win. If they would have, they may have lost their strength and will power because expectations would have made their shoulders weak. Probability and chances of failure would have created a mountain of fear.  Moral of the story- Winning may be an unrealistic goal. Trying with dedication and determination isn't!  One free tip- Focus on doing more than thinking and evaluating.

spend a lot of time figuring out what you personally like doing…like doing….enjoy doing…..not just what you’re good at or been trained for…..what you’d do even it was for free….then find a job/work etc where you can use that stuff….i was a stockbroker where i had no skills or desire…worked hard …drove myself without a minutes real pleasure…then i finally got sick of it…went on a what do i want to do http://thing….it turned out i was creative ( never really thought about myself as that ) …thought where i could put that to work along with other talents i had and got into advertising….i was good at it….but here’s the thing….i was a natural…it all came so easily…intuitively that’s how it will go with you once you figure out what you like doing….i used “what color is your parachute” which has been around and revised forever. the nice thing is when you figure out what “it” is you’ll know it immediately by how it feels. So two goals for you: find out what you personally enjoy doing- i don’t care it’s gardening ..cleaning fish….knitting…riding a garbage truck…military….numbers….cooking….police IT DOESN’T MATTER! get a job where that kind of job. your only goal after that will be finding a way to do more of it. Press on

Your terms “unrealistic goals” and “making life hard for myself” are rather vague. I suggest that you frame your life strategy in this way. If you have never taken a psychometric tests before, go to www. 123test_strengths and http://weaknesses.com Find out what work opportunities should you pursue for maximum success. Additionally, go and study The Color Code by Taylor Hartman. You will discover what is your dominant motivation - whether it is power, intimacy, peace, or fun. Then follow up by pursuing a path of spiritual growth by developing the 7 habits of highly effective people by Stephen Covey. Additionally, improve your productivity and decision-making by studying Six Thinking Hats by Edward de Bono. Achieve corporate success by studying Maximum Success by James Waldroop & Timothy Butler. Achieve financial security by emulating Warren Buffet in his biography: The Snowball: Warren Buffet and the Business of Life by Alice Schroeder. This holistic approach is far more effective then simply setting goals suggested by other people.

Why do you think your goals are unrealistic first of all? Is it because others don’t believe what you believe? Is it that they don’t support what you want and told you your goals were unrealistic, and that it couldn’t happen for you? If this is what you are dealing with, you need to understand something. Just because other people don’t understand or believe in your goals, does not mean your goals are unrealistic and unattainable. The first thing you need to do is BELIEVE IN YOURSELF. Despite what anyone else believes about you, YOU have to believe in YOU. If you have a lot of people around you who continue to cause you to second-guess yourself, stop telling them what your plans are. Sometimes, it’s even better to just remove certain people from your circle. You will have to take a look at those around you and figure out who is a benefit to your life and what you aspire to do and who is a detraction. Anyone who is not there to assist, encourage, or cheer you on, you need to cut them loose because they will keep you from your goals. I don’t know if you have ever heard the story about the wagon and the rope. It’s basically a scenario of a climb to success. You are carrying this heavy, thick rope over your bare shoulder and you are pulling this rusty heavy wagon up a hill the entire time. The hill represents the journey to your goals. The wagon represents the steps necessary to reach your goals. Well, along the way, you have people around you, because in order to reach your goals, you do need support. These people represent your friends, coworkers, business partners, even family. You have to be careful, because as they are around you, their job is to assist in getting that wagon up the hill. They are moving obstacles out of the way, pushing while you pull. What happens is — when you have people who are not for you, who don’t want to push, they will just jump on the wagon and ride, making your assent up that hill even harder. You have to get them off that wagon because they will make your climb agonizing. You will start to doubt yourself if you allow them to continue to hang on while you climb, carrying them on top of the weight of the wagon. This is a scenario that was told by Steve Harvey by someone he knew when he was on his own climb to success. So, I don’t know if you actually believe your goals are unrealistic, or if you are buying into what you have been told. Goals are attainable but the biggest and best ones are the hardest. So if you have set goals for yourself and you feel that they are too big and too hard to accomplish, those are usually the best goals. If it’s too easy, it’s not big enough. I believe you have been fed the wrong information. Just because it’s difficult doesn’t mean it’s unattainable. Start believing in yourself and in what you aspire for your future. Do your homework to see what or who in your life you need to put some distance between. Once you know what you want and believe in it just as passionately as you want it, the sky is the limit. But, it won’t happen if you don’t believe it yourself.

I would start by making a list of the things that just make me super happy that I cannot even explain. Then I would stare at that list and then look at the unrealistic / stressful goals list and compare and question myself. Is it worth it? Every moment, day, week, month, year that passes by is not coming back. What would I rather do? The answer should be simple. The other aspect here is going to the root cause of why you are being hard on yourself. Almost always there is a reason, you are not forgiving yourself for something or for someone in the past. Reflect on it , make peace with it and let it go. Whatever it is, its not worth hanging on to. The last but not the least is, we get addicted to the rush of the stress and do it deliberately. It is self destructive. Shift your focus to something that's positive, easy, and give yourself permission to love and pamper yourself. You are worth it. Always. Hope this helps. This is all from my own experience.

List all of your unrealistic goals. Rank them in order of importance to you. Take the number 1 ranked and break it into smaller, attainable goals. Try to have more than half of the sub goals be short term (< 1 month). Attaining these shorter term goals will provide you with some short-term positive reinforcement. The next 25.% of the sub goals should be attainable with 2 months and the final 25% within 3 months. If the larger goals require a longer period to attain, move them down the list. You want to focus on goals and sub goals that are realistically attainable within 3 months at the longest. As you increase your focus, and attain more goals, you should get better at setting more realistic and attainable goals. Good luck.

This is a quote by Norman Vincent Peale. “Shoot for the moon. Even if you miss, you'll land among the stars.” It means to set one's goals or ambitions very high; to try to attain or achieve something particularly difficult. Life, in general, is not easy, but each of us has the ability to make a difference in the quality of life, for ourselves, and our loved ones. I say set you goals, as usual, but break the path up into stages. Be patient. As you conquer each stage, recommit to attaining the end result, but only go to work to get to the next stage. This way you are always making progress, and you are not feeling any disappointment for not reaching the final stage. Believe me, it is a lifelong process, and you have nothing to gain but complete fulfillment.

Hi, the moment you decide. YOU DECIDE. Remember that everything you think (and do) takes you to one of the two: a hard life, or a (… you name it, non-hard) life. Decide what you’d like your life be (name it, describe it, the more precisely, the better), and think the way, and take the actions that reflect it. Like a mirror. Don’t say, for example, you want an wonderful life and then dress ugly or punish yourself. Keep things wonderful in your mind and “life”, and that’s how it will be. As for goals, you need none, If you WANT, you may have pieces and slices of you-name-it your kind of life, and go from there. As this is thw first and most important step - your decision - you may want personalised assistance (like a coach) to help you streamline, keeping yourself accountable and celebrating progress with. And quicken the change, and make it permanent. All the best, thanks for a2a, beautiful question.

Don’t let others set your expectations you do what you can do within your means. You should set 2 targets if you must a lower target which must not be too high and another aspiration target which is lofty.Staggered your targets and set them higher as you make progress. My targets are aspirational and my plans are 100 years divided into 4x 25 year segments. First segment is to get an education second segment get a job in my profession and raise family third is to be a businessman, fortj is about leaving a legacy eg inter generational planning. I don’t feel any stress as my plans are a very long duration I can make mistakes and still meet targets.

Take a goal and break it down as much as possible. Determine each small step towards that goal in order. Write it down and hang it in a visible area. As you accomplish each goal then cross it off. Reward yourself for reaching each goal, not in a big way but thank yourself. Literally your whole life is reaching and accomplishing goals in one way or another. That said, keep your goals specific, attainable, and a small reward after each. I totally understand setting unrealistic goals and feeling let down. Prepare for the worst in any situation and work towards the best. Most importantly, be honest and realistic about your vision/definition of success. You must make enough money to live without worrying or being afraid you can't pay your bills. Keep that in the forefront of your mind always. Be grateful and keep moving forward

Find job that suits you and start working immediately. Make small monthly weekly and daily goals and start achieving them try with very small. And increase skills try to learn and master as much as skills you can learn. Choose purpose for life and make long term plan. When you make plan keep in mind that plan should be ready for worst situations and potential for best. Example : If you want to be healthy start working 5 minutes day and increase day by day as your capabilities. You can some apps that provides exercise that you can start doing daily.

First you need to contemplate on what you really want to do in your life. Do you want to pursue a hobby, a talent, a profession or a passion? Often confusion arises when the time comes to set goals. Not all are lucky and get to do what they want. But it's best to meet challenges as they come. Become a learner. Learn from them and carry on. All goals are unrealistic till they are met, don't you think? Life is such. “Man proposes, God disposes”, we have to accept this. We don't know what we're going to get. It will always remain a mystery. So don't think life is hard. To carry on you have to set goals. Reaching there will be your destiny. Cheer up and get going.

By setting small, attainable goals. You’re probably a dreamer, an idealist - I can totally relate to that. But if you want to get shit done, you have to tame your ideas. You don’t have to stop dreaming up cool stuff, you just have to break it down into smaller parts. If you dream up a castle, keep that image in mind, but then break it down to its smaller parts. You need a crew, you need bricks, you need an architect, etc. I don’t think that most goals are unrealistic. It sounds more like they’re just too big to tackle all by yourself or all at once. Break it down, dissect it. If you can’t bother to go through with the small stuff, then the goal wasn’t really that important to you in the end. Sometimes, some stuff just feels romantic and ideal… until we drag it back down to Earth and realize that it’s a massive pain to produce it and we’re just not into it as much as we thought we were.

By realizing your potential and limits, before you jump to conclusions by saying I don’t have limits. Please realize I’m try to point out that there are areas in your goals that you need to work on. Goal are not unattainable, there just set back, what I mean is that their there (Goals). But, you just haven’t reach it yet. In today society. Everything has to be done at a certain time. But reality is you don’t. Again that all depends on your situation. Set little Goals and keep doing it until your ready to up your Goal. This is way to get you in routine and at the same know what your good at and not so good at. Best of luck DP

Unrealistic goals are situational. Change the situation, and what is unrealistic becomes realistic. It is pretty simple, but not always easy, depending on your own personal characteristics. It’s a matter of pooling resources. Being receptive to learning everything that needs to be learned in order to accomplish the tasks ahead. Inspiring those around you to use their natural abilities for the good of the dream. How do you stop setting unrealistic goals? Just get more competent.

Life is simple, don't make it hard. if you will follow everything be on time...About the goal, 1st of all you are lucky, you have goal in your life....Nothing is impossible everything is possible... Ask to yourself how is it possible...Think big but you can't achieve big in one time....You must go step by step process.... You must have patience and persistence.... You must have continuity in thing...Example:-Suppose you have goal for buy chatted flight.... but you don't have bike also....!st of all think I will buy a bike before 01/01/2020. (after achieve)After that create a goal I will buy a car before 01/01/2021.(after achieve)After that create a goal for Mercedes...After that you can create a goal for chatted flight.... How it will happen , You will ask question to yourself....whenever you will ask question, Definitely find out answer.... If you can achieve small thing, You can achieve everything... Your success is my wishes...Thank you....

Take a good at these unrealistic goals and think what it was actually take to achieve them then determine whether they are actually attainable or not. Forf example, if I set a goal to climb up the side of the Empire State Building, that would be an unrealistic goal that I would never be able to achieve. And I can make that decision right now because I'm thinking about what it would take to reach that goal. And I don't possess those things. Good Luck, L

Just thinking, maybe you could categorize your goal lists into : 1. Doable 2. Requires a Miracle. It would help to remember that miracles can happen (or not). So just go by simple faith and simple prayer, and if what you set out for didn’t happen, even though you gave it your best try, it might be wise to just let it go, with an uncomplicated and simple “goodbye.” Move past it, and make wiser selections on goals, establishing a reality check.

Thanks Pallav for a2a. I have answered a question that will help clear what should exactly be the plan. Goal setting and going for wrong aims and objectives are issues that are important to be addressed early in life. Please go through this, my answer is included in three answers: What is your plan to make your life’s goal come true? Here is additional help material from internet searching. Please make the best use of what is written: Eight Common Goal-Setting Mistakes – Achieving Your Dreams the Right Way How to Get Rid of Unrealistic Goals Wish the best.

In order to set realistic, achievable goals and also have the constant inspiration, motivation, tools to reach them, we need a unique, closed, mutually supportive and mutually complementing environment. What we can't reach, accomplish alone, we can easily achieve mutually together as a result of a proper, methodical, purposeful teamwork. Group Or Individual? | Laitman.com New Life #322 – The Desire To Succeed | Laitman.com

First of all, you are setting goals, sounds like you are an idealist and you set them high, nothing wrong with that and nothing wrong with making life hard for yourself. Are they unrealistic in your mind when you set them, like for example before we learned to fly by plane early man must have tried to fly by waving its arms, unrealistic yes but it lead to the next thought and the next till here we are.

Setting goals is a lot like making a budget. Goals shouldn’t just be targets on the wall, they should have measurable resources allocated to them. If you know exactly what resources you need to allocate to a goal, and are able to allocate them, then it is a realistic goal. Prioritize the goals for which your resource allocations are measured and available, everything else is just a wish-list.

Remember that the best way to achieve your target is by “a set of baby steps done consistently”… This way you are less intimidated by the “size” of the step, you collect “successes” on the way and strengthen you self confidence, and leave room to listen to feedback on the way and see if this route is leading to the experience you were looking for when setting your goal. Not to sound cinical, and not knowing anything about you, I venture to say that many times people are “making life hard for themselves” as a habit and possibly it provides them a sense of “I can handle anything”… but this is counter-productive.

You are probably not breaking the goals down enough. Big goals are good, they are just not easily realisable. Chunk them into parts that can be accomplished in a day, week, or month. Over time, as you accomplish the “sub-tasks”, you will be accomplishing your overarching goals. Maybe what you have is purpose rather than goals. Translate that into things you can do every day. J

Do your self a favor. Number one, take it one day at a time, save $10 dollars a day. Number two, schedule your calender for a solid 3 to 4 weeks. Number three: it will take you one month just to take care of those quality professional items you needed to attend to, of those 3 to 4 weeks of tasks. Keep doing that, you will be fine. Dont make it about everything, your taking a big bit all at once. Good luck

Be realistic, set goals for yourself and not someone else's expectation of you, we sometimes miss the boat on ourselves, and live for others, you can't live up to those goals, be clear about what you want, and keep on track, you have to please and satisfy you, and in time and a plan and those goals set in stone you will be less frustrated by unrealistic goals!

Start out setting smaller more realistic goals you can easily achieve. For instance if you want to paint a house, set a goal to only paint for ten minutes a day. After a few days you will forget about painting for only ten minutes a day and the house will be done within the week. When you set your goals to high you become overwhelmed. Break your goals into smaller pieces.

Set daily or weekly goals that are achievable. Set a deadline to finish a report or presentation rather than you’ll close 100 new deals this month. Set goals on things you have control over. “I will send out ten new proposals this week”—this means you need to contact XX number of prospects and from their 10 will ask for a proposal. You are NOT saying that you will close business, however hopefully you know that for every 10 proposals-you close an average of five—so you should have 3–7 new deals—This is a byproduct of your goal of sending 10 new proposals out this week.

Namsthe First make sure whatever goals you set makes you happy and allows you to be in peace, it has to be your goal, do not set goals just because someone told you or to please someone, it has to make you happy. Only then you get interested in it and put in all your efforts to achieve it.

Set 5 year goals instead of 6 month goals. Then set smaller goals in order to achieve your 5 year goals. I used to set 6 month or 1 year goals, but after 20 years, I hadn’t achieved some of them. Changing the goal posts and targets for these particularly difficult challenges has changed my life. Good luck in your quest.

Unrealistic goals just add more stress to your life. You will only make your life harder which is why you begin with baby steps. Take one thing that is most important, make a list and check off what you have accomplished. You’ll feel so much better seeing those check marks and soon you’ll figure out that bigger steps are attainable.

Let go ,stop all your goals stop thinking about making life harder than it is ,don't think too much about happenings life will take its on course just live one day at a time think about being happy and the rest it takes its own course ,remember don't think too much.

How about setting up a really simple task like doing the laundry, please look at the state of your own comfort zone is it clean or messy? how are you expecting to be a high achiever if your house is not clean and organized plus the environment perfectly decorated to stimulate your behavior towards your goals.

First understand the difference between a goal and a desire. A goal is something that you have 100% power to achieve. A desire always involves input from other sources and or people. Happy goal keeping. Serene desires. It is OK to have many and large desires so long as you NEVER hang on expectation.

You have to set goals that you can smash. Also taking time to really introspect and see what your desires are can be helpful. Looking inward and meditating in this way can make your life much easier. If you’d like further discussion you can always message me. Hare Krishna!

Change your belief that life is hard. By doing that one thing, your life will change. You’ll approach challenges differently and you’ll view life differently. It’s pretty amazing how your life can change once you change your beliefs.

Whenever you are setting goals, you must follow the guidelines - SMART SpecificMeasurableAchievableRealisticTime bound.If it is unrealistic or non achievable, you cannot have such a goal. Goals are supposed to motivate you and not otherwise.

Put your focus on setting smaller, realistic goals. Small goals that lead you too that main goal. Reward yourself (in some way) after achieving each smaller goal. Develop this as a habit over time. Then the unrealistic goals will become reality.

By setting the goals the right way. Look up SMART goals. Best yest read Eat that frog. Eat That Frog!: 21 Great Ways to Stop Procrastinating and Get More Done in Less Time: Brian Tracy: 9781626569416: Books Its a small book but powerful.

No goal is unrealistic with a fair share of hard work and patience. Create short term goals and try to accomplish those first. Once they are accomplished you’ll get a feeling of satisfaction and get the instant motivation to create more goals which will ultimately lead you to your long-term goal.

Thanks for A2A, Survival and Life are not the same, you have to work for survival because you are alive.. life is not just about surviving.. stop looking at yourself from other's perspective, as every individual is blessed with different capabilities and qualities.. so, respect the diversity blessed by the nature and live life to experience every moment.. Whatever you do, be involved absolutely and give your best.. that's what you can do.. you not giving your best should worry you not the outcome..

The total is never greater than the sum of its parts. Break the goal down into achievable steps then you can determine if it’s realistic or not. Like the old saying, “How do you eat an elephant? One bite at a time.”
There is NO SUCH THING as unrealistic goals! However, YOU are making your life hard for yourself, by stating your question! Change your thinking and change your life! Peace
I’m sorry after reading your profile I feel you are doomed to making unrealistic goals for the rest of your life or until you grow up.
There is nothing called an unrealistic goal. Everything is possible. So, set goals as high as you can. Believe that you can do. Reprogram your subconscious mind. And achieve it
Divide the unrealistic goal into smaller achievable bite size goals and enjoy the additional rewards for success
If you know the problem you will find the solution. Don't overthing. Best of luck.
Chandler's answer to How can I make my personal life goals more realistic and achievable?
Yes, you can. You are your own competition. You know know about yourself better than others
Prayer will help you.
